table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, and not to any letter or glyph.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a kind of plant, rather than the finely-ground spice.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is used when referring to disruptors ({nISwI':n}), and is distinct from {baH:v}. The object of this verb is the {tIH:n:1} "energy beam" which is fired, for example, {nISwI' tIH bach:sen@@nISwI':n, tIH:n:1, bach:v}. In practice, the word {tIH:n:1,nolink} is commonly dropped, and one simply says {nISwI' bach:sen@@nISwI':n, bach:v} instead.[2]
The suffix {-Daq:n} marks the target.

{baH:v:nolink} is pronounced like the name of the Terran composer "Bach" by speakers of American English.
That the target is marked with {-Daq:n:nolink} is known from {SkyBox 14:src} and a deleted line from {Star Trek V:src} (see under {vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.:sen}).

table.name: mem
table.column: See {KGT p.145:src} for an explanation of this verb.
This is the first word in the Klingon-English side of the dictionary portion of {KGT:src}, where it is incorrectly listed as a noun as a joke.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This slang term is used for figuring out how to decrypt previously encrypted data (and successfully doing so), without knowing how to do so ahead of time. That is, it refers to unauthorized decryption.[1]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: In one traditional form of duel, the goal of each of the male combatants is to "win the favor of a woman" ({vuv be' 'e' baj:sen@@vuv:v, be':n, 'e':n, baj:v}, literally, "earn that a woman respects him").[1, p.69]
A "badge" is something that has to be earned.

table.name: mem
table.column: Sounds like "bowl", or "bottle" in some accents where the middle consonant is a very short glottal stop.

table.name: mem
table.column: face, have the prospect of having to deal with

table.name: mem
table.column: Bananas are known to bruise easily.

table.name: mem
table.column: companion, darling, dear, lover, mate, partner, romantic

table.name: mem
table.column: These are usually specific to a couple, and almost never uttered unless the couple is alone. A pet name is formed by adding the suffix {-oy:n:suff} to a noun.[1, p.199]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used to signal surrender in a duel.

table.name: mem
table.column: toss bat'leth from one hand to the other
This is also used for taking turns (see {baQ:v:3}).

table.name: mem
table.column: be fresh, be just picked (fruit, vegetable)

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an extension of {baQ:v:1} to gaming or other situations where players, etc., act in a predefined order. To specify someone's turn, use {jop:v:2}.

table.name: mem
table.column: When used for booing, it is often preceded or followed by general grumbling and growling. Sometimes, just grumbling and growling alone can also expressed this sentiment.[2]

This was defined in {TKD:src} as "general invective". At {qep'a' 26 (2019):src}, it was explained that this could be used as the equivalent to the English "boo! hiss!"
In Japanese, "baka" means "fool" or "idiot".

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to light up briefly or repeatedly.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: Victor Basta is a character in the movie "Airplane!" He is asked, "What's our vector, Victor?"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a Klingon game or contest which is similar to arm wrestling.

table.name: mem
table.column: honor (general, philosophical concept, associated with integrity)
This word refers to a grander, more general, philosophical concept, in comparison to {quv:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: You will be remembered with honor.

table.name: mem
table.column: An honorable death requires no vengeance.
The reason that it's {noDnISbe' vay':sen:nolink} and not {noDnISbe'lu':sen:nolink} is because multiple uses of {-lu':v} (see the note in that entry) would refer to the same indefinite subject.
An honourable death requires no vengeance.

table.name: mem
table.column: batlh potlh law' yIn potlh puS.
Honor is more important than life.
Honour is more important than life.

table.name: mem
table.column: A Klingon does not postpone a matter of honor.
A Klingon does not postpone a matter of honour.

table.name: mem
table.column: Defend the Klingon race with honor.
This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {batlhHa' vanglu'taHvIS quv chavbe'lu'.:sen} ▶ {Qu' buSHa'chugh SuvwI', batlhHa' vangchugh, qoj matlhHa'chugh, pagh ghaH SuvwI''e'.:sen}
dishonourably, dishonored, dishonoured, without honor, without honour

table.name: mem
table.column: One does not achieve honor while acting dishonorably.
One does not achieve honour while acting dishonourably.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is the thing being orbited. {-Daq:n:suff} is unnecessary.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be comfortable, be feeling prepared, be confident
This might be used to describe feeling prepared for an upcoming journey or battle.

table.name: mem
table.column: be uncomfortable, be worried, be hesitant
This might be used to describe feeling unprepared for an upcoming journey or battle.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the chunk cut off as a result of {quH:v}.
This is {bay:n} "b" plus {laD:v} "read", a reference to sliced bread.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the seat strapped to the back of an animal.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Bazooka Joe" is the mascot of the Bazooka brand of bubble gum. {ba'Suq'a' jo':sen@@ba'Suq:n, -'a':n, jo':v:1} means "he blows a great bubble".

table.name: mem
table.column: The {yor:n} of a {qach:n}, and the top face of a {pa' beb:n}.
"Babe Ruth" was an American baseball player.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a person who lays out the shingles, planks, etc., when constructing a roof.

table.name: mem
table.column: Possibly from the expression "bitch and moan".

table.name: mem
table.column: Two common kinds of {beH:n} are {nISwI' beH:n} and {pu'beH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: be sure, be definite, be positive, be certain
This may be used when there is an object (unlike {na':v:2,slang,nolink}).[1, p.145]

▶ {jIbej.:sen:nolink} "I am positive [about something I just said]."[1, p.145] ▶ {bIbej'a'?:sen:nolink} "Are you sure?"[1, p.145] ▶ {HIvrup 'e' vIbej.:sen:nolink} "I am positive they're read to attack."[1, p.145]

table.name: mem
table.column: The English translation of the sentence from {Star Trek Constellations:src} does not appear in the book, but in the author's annotations which was a separate document.
▶ {chobelHa'moH, DI'qar. SajlIj 'oHbe' quvwIj'e'.:sen:nolink} "You disappoint me, D'Kar. My honor is not your play-thing."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
In Klingon, instead of saying "I am X years old", one's age is expressed by saying "I was born X years ago."[2]
To say "when I was X years old", the construction is, for example, {qaStaHvIS DISwIj javDIch...:sen@@qaS:v, -taH:v, -vIS:v, DIS:n:2, -wIj:n, jav:n:1, -DIch:n} "When I was six years old...". The time between birth and the first birthday is considered the zeroth year.[4]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This refers to a member of a ship's company ({wey:n}) who is not an officer ({yaS:n}).[2]
The word {yaS:n:nolink} is also used for a member of an official body that has regulatory authority of some sort. For a more loosely organized group, one with no governmental- or military-like status, {beq:n:nolink} is the most common way to refer to a member.[3]

A crewman is at "beck" and call.
In the episode {DS9 - Sons and Daughters:src}, this word (Anglicised "bekk") was treated as a rank given to enlisted personnel in the Klingon Defense Force ({tlhIngan Hubbeq:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: type of mineral, bekpuj (orange in color)
This word may contain the element {puj:n:2,hyp} also found in {cha'puj:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined in {TKD:src} only as "be irritable", but {berghmoH:v} "irritate" from {KGT:src} suggests that {bergh:v:nolink} can mean "be irritated".

table.name: mem
table.column: end (of an opera, play, story, speech)

This refers to the final section of a performance (last aria in an opera, last speech in a play, last sentence or so in a story or speech, etc.). For a song (and only for a song), the final portion is called its {'o'megh:n}.
This is a reference to Bertram from Shakespeare's "All's Well That Ends Well".

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a state of matter.
Bette Graham was the inventor of liquid paper (correction fluid).

table.name: mem
table.column:
The elements of the name of this weapon are archaic, but it means "sword of honor". In modern Klingon, of course, "sword of honor" would be {batlh 'etlh:n:nolink}. See {paq'batlh:n}.
In Klingon legend, the original Sword of Honor was forged by {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} from a lock of his hair dipped into the {qul ngeng:n} of the volcano {QIStaq:n}. The weapon is shaped like a {maS'e' loQ So'be'bogh QIb:n}.[5]
The {betleH:n:nolink} is also called the {betleH quv:n:nolink}, to differentiate it from the similar sounding {meqleH:n}.
This word is misspelled {batleH:n:hyp,nolink} on {SkyBox 8:src}.[3] A message on the {s.k:src} newsgroup gives a bit of history behind the various spellings used in English for this word.[4]

▶ {qaStaHvIS wa'maH puq poHmey, wo'rIv betleH ghaj qorDu'Daj. nuja' tlhIngan wIch ja'wI'pu' yIntaHvIS qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay' batlh 'etlhvam chenmoHlu'pu'.:sen:nolink} "Worf's bat'telh has been in his family for ten generations. According to Klingon legend, this sword of honor descends from the time of Kahless the Unforgettable."[3]
batleth, bat'telh, sword of honor, sword of honour

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the metallic chemical element with the symbol Al and atomic number 13.
The chorus of the Paul Simon song "You Can Call Me Al" has the line "And Betty, when you call me, you can call me Al."

table.name: mem
table.column: mixture of ingredients for producing fermented {HIq:n}
This is a mixture of ingredients that, after a bit of time, produces fermented {HIq:n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This might have been shortened from something like {bewSom roghmeH qegh pa':n:nolink}, but this isn't certain.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Bay" is an English word with the same meaning.

table.name: mem
table.column: This expression is known only through the sentence, from {SkyBox 31:src}, {beyHom bey bey'a' jachtaH latlh tlhInganpu'.:sen:nolink} "[Other Klingons] roar in a great crescendo."[1] Its exact grammar is unclear.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the way the name of B'Elanna Torres is pronounced, which isn't pronounced in a very Klingon way. The Klingon version of a name transcribed as "B'Elanna" would be {be'elanna:n:name,nolink} or {be'ela'na:n:name,nolink} or {bI'Ila'na:n:name,nolink} or something like that.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to a financial establishment.
This is a reference to the Bailey Bros. Building & Loan Association, from the movie "It's a Wonderful Life". There is also a chain of jewellery stores called "Bailey Banks & Biddle".

table.name: mem
table.column: Known types of {bey':n:nolink} include the {betleH bey':n}, the {quv bey':n}, and the {nuH bey':n}.
In architecture, a "bay" is an opening or hole, such as a recess in a wall where something may be displayed.

table.name: mem
table.column: The suffix for the plural of this word depends on whether it is used to refer to beings capable of language (see {-pu':n:suff}) or not (see {-mey:n:suff}).

table.name: mem
table.column: Sister of Lursa and Duras. She is portrayed by the actress {ghuwI'nItlh wa'lIS:n:name}.

▶ {DuraS tuq tlhIngan yejquv patlh luDub 'e' reH lunIDtaH DuraS be'nI'pu' lurSa' be'etor je. ngoQvam luchavmeH ghawran maghpu' be'nI'pu'. woQ luSuqmeH jIjpu' chaH romuluSngan'e' je.:sen:nolink} "The sisters of the House of Duras, Lursa and B'Etor, are constantly seeking a higher standing for the House of Duras within the Klingon High Council. To this end, the sisters have acted against Gowron, going as far as to work with Romulan factions in order to gain power."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: A "sister-in-law" is {loDnI' be'nal:n@@loDnI':n, be'nal:n} or {be'nI' be'nal:n@@be'nI':n, be'nal:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Federation. Its inhabitants are telepaths.

table.name: mem
table.column: The medical abbreviation "b.i.d.", short for the Latin "bis in die", means "twice a day".

table.name: mem
table.column: For notes on the grammar of this sentence, see {bIjeghbe'chugh vaj bIHegh!:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: Jail is referred to in slang as the "big house".
▶ {bIghHa'Daq yIghoS:sen:nolink} "Go to jail"[1, p.170] ▶ {bIghHa' yIjaH:sen:nolink} "Go to jail"[2]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: If you are afraid to die, you have already died.

table.name: mem
table.column: If you say the wrong thing, I will kill you.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined on {TKD p.172:src} as "Be quiet! (i.e., Stop speaking!)", and in {PK:src} as "Shut up!"

table.name: mem
table.column:
This sentence literally means, "If you don't surrender, you will die". Note that even though the English translation has "or" in it, the conjunction {pagh:conj} is not used in the Klingon sentence. In general, English sentences of the form "X or Y!" (demanding that the listener choose one out of the two options) must be recast as {bI-X-be'chugh vaj bI-Y:sen:nolink} "If you don't X, you will Y" in Klingon.
Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/NpFDKTzINH8}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is often said by Klingon merchants to their customers. See the similar {bIjeghbe'chugh vaj bIHegh!:sen} for analysis.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a capricious, eccentric, and often sudden idea or fancy.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: If you cannot fail, you cannot succeed.

table.name: mem
table.column: second tone of nonatonic musical scale
The tones of the Klingon musical scale (see {yutlhegh:n}) are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n:nolink}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.
Instead of "ray", which is "a drop of golden sun", this is a "beam".

table.name: mem
table.column: May you encounter Kahless in your dreams.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {bIS'ub:n} and {pIrmuS:n} for the bottom parts of an object. See also {lurgh:n} for other words related to spatial directions.

table.name: mem
table.column: The Greek word "hypothesis" comes from roots meaning "under" ({bIng:n}) and "placing" ({lan:v}).

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a number-forming element, and not itself a number. The number 100,000 (one hundred thousand) is {wa'nIp:n:num,nolink} in Klingon.
Note that the Klingon number-forming element for "hundred thousand" is independent of the words for "hundred" ({vatlh:n:num}) and "thousand" ({SaD:n:num}). The Klingon {bIp:n:num,nolink} is equivalent to the "lakh" which is used in South Asian numbering systems on Earth.
For tens of millions, one could combine {maH:n:2,num} with {'uy':n:num,nolink} or {vatlh:n:num} with {bIp:n:num}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Water is used as the symbol of weakness and disdain. This idea is expressed in the Klingon idiom {puj; bIQ rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used for a ship that travels on water.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the room in which Terrans spray themselves with water. (Yuck.)
This is defined in {TNK:src} as "shower", but it clearly refers to the room.

table.name: mem
table.column: Brackish water is the best water for tea.[1, p.96]

table.name: mem
table.column: be quite mistaken, be totally wrong
This literally means "The cup contains water." It is a reasonably strong expression, and it would not be surprising if a fight broke out after this is uttered.

table.name: mem
table.column: Historically or etymologically, this was no doubt formed from {bIQ SeHmeH jan:n} by dropping the {-meH:v}. This could happen for other words (e.g., {voD jan:n}), but is not a productive process. Except for some set, accepted expressions, dropping the {-meH:v:nolink} is considered odd, but people may do this anyway in everyday conversation.

The grammar was discussed during the Q & A session, and afterwards MO released a document providing further details. MO originally replied to the request for "faucet" by suggesting {bIQ SeH jan:sen@@bIQ:n, SeH:v, jan:n:1}, which is a sentence meaning "the device controls the water", which led to some confusion as it was interpreted as a noun.

table.name: mem
table.column: The common way to say this is {bIQ SeHjan:n:nolink}, but this is also fine.

table.name: mem
table.column: This covers most animals that live in the sea, such as dolphins, whales, fish, and octopuses, but not smaller animals such as shrimps or water bugs, or amphibians. Every {ghotI':n} is a {bIQDep:n:nolink}, but not every {bIQDep:n:nolink} is a {ghotI':n:nolink}.[2]
This was defined as "fish" in {KGT:src}[1], but was clarified to refer to any sea or water-based creature later.[2]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This literally means the edge ({HeH:n}) of the ocean ({bIQ'a':n}). A beach by a lake would be called a {ngeng HeH:n}, and so on.

table.name: mem
table.column: The sword is in the ocean.
This idiom means that something has ended, and it is impossible to return to the previous condition.

table.name: mem
table.column: To really succeed, you must enjoy eating poison.

table.name: mem
table.column: bIQongtaHvIS nItlhejchugh targhmey bIvemDI' nItlhej ghIlab ghewmey.
If you sleep with targs, you'll wake up with glob flies.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a specific type of {chabHom:n} that's sort of two {chabHommey:n:nolink} stuck together like a sandwich.
"Hydrox" is a brand of cookie sandwich which derives its name from the components of water, hydrogen ({bIQSIp:n}) and oxygen ({yInSIp:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: The temperature words really are about temperature and not about effect or perception, so that clothing, for example, is not said to be "hot" or "cold" in Klingon (but the person wearing it is).[3]

A cold "beer", or alternatively, "brrrr" is the sound one makes when one is cold.
The clarification about clothing was made during the Q & A session at {qep'a' 27 (2020):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The blood of the warrior grows cold.
To discourage romantic attention from someone, turn your side to them, and say this sentence.

table.name: mem
table.column: If the qIvon is cold, the blood is hot.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a ceremony in which the killer of the head of a Klingon house marries the widow and becomes the head of the house himself. The language associated with this ceremony is in a form of {no' Hol:n}.[1, p.11]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon by itself, but can be inferred from {bIreQtagh:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This dish may be made from the breathing organ of any of a number of beasts. Even though this dish may consist of pieces of lung from more than one bregit, it is never called "bregit lungs".[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: Even though {TKD:src} says that {-bej:v} (and other type 6 verb suffixes) are about the speaker's certainty about what's being said, in this sentence this uncertainty seems to be applied to the subject.

table.name: mem
table.column: If you must negotiate, watch your enemy's eyes.

table.name: mem
table.column: For example, this word would be used to describe the inside bottom of a box. The other face of the box's {bIS'ub:n:nolink} is its {pIrmuS:n}.

In Ovid's "Metamorphoses", Pyramus and Thisbe are lovers who are separated by being on opposite sides of a wall.
Speculation: This may have been intended to be {tIS'ub:n:nolink} but was changed due to a transcription error (or another reason).

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {bIt; tI'qa' vIghro' rur@@bIt:v, tI'qa' vIghro':n, rur:v}.[2]

As the saying goes: once bitten, twice shy.
On {KGT p.132:src}, the word is written as {tIb:v:nolink} instead of {bIt:v:nolink}, but this is clearly a typo.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is an exclamation which serves a similar role to "oh, yeah?" in expressing disbelief or defiance. However, it differs from "oh, yeah?" in that it lacks the sense of exasperation. (Among members of the Federation, "oh, yeah?" is said in the course of an argument when one can think of nothing better to say to make one's next point. For Klingons, exasperation is not an admirable characteristic.) If one Klingon says this to another, one should either stand back or get closer, depending on whether one thinks a fight or stimulating round of curse warfare is about to begin.[1]
The expression carries the element of defiance only when the pronominal prefix is second-person. (The form used when addressing a group is {SutaHrup'a'?:sen@@Su-:v, taH:v:1, -rup:v, -'a':v}) Even with a second-person prefix, in a context which is clearly nonconfrontational, the phrase {bItaHrup'a'?:sen:nolink} or {SutaHrup'a'?:sen:nolink} could be used to convey its literal meaning, "Are you ready to continue?" However, the defiant sense of the expression is more common.[1]
Maltz felt sure that there is a connection between this expression and the expletive {taHqeq:excl}, but he couldn't explain what it was.[1]
For "oh, yeah?" meaning simply "Is that so?", see {qar'a'?:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: If you cannot be shamed, you cannot be honored.
If you cannot be shamed, you cannot be honoured.

table.name: mem
table.column: adapt to, get used to, acclimatize to, conform to, become adjusted to

table.name: mem
table.column: You do not deserve to live.
This sentence is spoken in Klingon in the opening sequence to {PK:src}, but no English translation is provided.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiomatic expression, {pe'vIl bI'chu':sen} "forcefully sweep away", which means to do something all at once, as a single event.[1, p.112]

▶ {romuluSnganpu' Dujmey DIQaw'pu'; pe'vIl DIbI'chu'pu'.:sen@@romuluSngan:n, -pu':n, Duj:n:1, -mey:n, DI-:v, Qaw':v, -pu':v, pe'vIl:adv, DI-:v, bI':v, -chu':v, -pu':v} "We destroyed the Romulans' ships all at once."

table.name: mem
table.column: beginning (of an opera, play, story, speech)
This refers to the opening section of a performance (first act, scene, sentence, etc.).
These are the first two syllables of the Torah.
▶ {bI'reS qeylIS vaq molor:sen:nolink} "First, Molor taunts Kahless"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
{tlhIH:n}:{ghaH:n}/{'oH:n}/{chaH:n}/{bIH:n} = {bo-:v:pref,nolink}
When used with {-lu':v}, this prefix means "Someone (indefinite subject) does something to you (plural)".

table.name: mem
table.column:
Matches lip movement.
For the Pittsburgh Art Tour, Marc Okrand suggested to translate "space capsule" as {logh bobcho':n@@logh:n, bobcho':n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Splish Splash" is a song by Bobby Darin.
▶ {bobDar tlhen:sen@@bobDar:n, tlhen:v} "(it) produces a splash sound"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {boch; ghIch rur@@boch:v, ghIch:n, rur:v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is derived from an earlier expression {'etlh bochmoHwI':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: Klingons are born, live as warriors, then die.

table.name: mem
table.column: A reference to the Colonel Bogey March.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is explicitly stated on {KGT p.147:src} that the non-slang meaning of this verb does not take an object.

table.name: mem
table.column: The slang definition of this verb appears in the discussion on {bolwI':n} on {KGT p.147:src}, but is not found in the word lists in that book. This is the reverse of {lob:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Possibly from "boll weevil", from American Civil War history.

table.name: mem
table.column: Kinds of {bom:n:nolink} include: {bang bom:n}, {HIvje' bom:n}, {van bom:n}, {chon bom:n}, {Dap bom:n}, {ghe'naQ:n}, {may' bom:n}, {najmoHwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {bomDI' 'IwwIj qaqaw.:sen} ▶ {bom; puq rur:sen@@bom:v, puq:n, rur:v} (sing falsetto)[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: The memory of you sings in my blood.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is a Klingon idiom, {'oj; bomwI' rur@@'oj:v, bomwI':n, rur:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: When {A:sen:nolink} shares {C:sen:nolink} with {B:sen:nolink}, the construction is {B-vaD C bon A:sen:nolink} (with appropriate verb prefixes depending on {A:sen:nolink} and {C:sen:nolink}). In this case, {C:sen:nolink} belongs to {A:sen:nolink} and {A:sen:nolink} chooses to share it with {B:sen:nolink}.

Share a "bond".
Reverse of {nob:v}. This was apparently not intentional.

table.name: mem
table.column: The refrain to the Hokey Pokey, "that's what it's all about", is {'e' bop:sen:nolink} in Klingon.
▶ {HolQeD bopbe' paqvam.:sen@@HolQeD:n, bop:v, -be':v, paq:n:1h, -vam:n} "This book is not about linguistics."

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {boq lucherDI' tlhIngan wo' romuluS Hov wo' je So'wI' cham Suqpu' tlhIngan wo'.:sen:nolink} "Cloaking technology was gained through an alliance with the Romulan Star Empire"[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: ally with, form an alliance with
This word is also used in mathematics for addition (see {boq:v:2}).

table.name: mem
table.column: The four basic arithmetic operations are: + {boq:v:2,nolink}, - {boqHa':v}, × {boq'egh:v}, ÷ {boqHa''egh:v}. In these operations, numbers are treated as if they are grammatically singular.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {cha'logh boq'egh wej; chen jav:sen:nolink} 2 × 3 = 6 ▶ {pIraqSIS HoS waw' ghajlu'chugh, loSlogh boq'egh mI' naghmey mI'; chen qav'ap.:sen:nolink} "If Praxis Energy Facility is owned, rent is 4 times amount shown on dice."

table.name: mem
table.column: This term and {boQ Hol:n} are used interchangeably.

table.name: mem
table.column: Its livers are eaten as {boqrat chej Qevlu'pu'bogh:n@@boqrat:n, chej:n, Qev:v, -lu':v, -pu':v, -bogh:v} "stewed bokrat liver".
{boqrat chej:n:nolink} is listed in the glossary to {Diplomatic Implausibility:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Which plural suffix this takes depends on the type of symbiont. In the case of Trill (see {tI'rIlngan:n}) symbionts, the suffix {-pu':n:suff} is used. In the case of a parasite, use {-mey:n:suff}.
The plural suffix this word takes was clarified during the Q & A session.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a person who assists someone.

"Boq" is the name of a character in The Wizard of Oz who assists Dorothy.
Marc Okrand ({marq 'oqranD:n:name}) is billed as Associate Producer, translated as {chenmoHwI' boQ:n@@chenmoHwI':n, boQ:n:1}, in the film {Conlanging:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Boq" is the name of a character in The Wizard of Oz who assists Dorothy.

table.name: mem
table.column: This would be used in situations where someone might be able to do a task alone, but it's easier or better or more efficient if someone helps out. The object of {boQ:v:nolink} retains the responsibility for the activity being aided. This is in contrast to {QaH:v}.[2]
"Boq" is the name of a character in The Wizard of Oz who assists Dorothy.

table.name: mem
table.column: This specifically refers to the sound that a stomach makes.
"Borborygmus" is an onomatopoetic word referring to the rumbling sound made by intestinal gas.

table.name: mem
table.column: The non-slang way to say "thunder" is {tuD:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Watch the lecture on Klingon (by Marc Okrand) in which this word appears: {YouTube video:url:https://youtu.be/5G_v20YlwWc?t=3600}

This was spoken by MO in response to a question about how to say "Borg" or "Vulcan" in Klingon.
It's unclear if this is a loanword from English or if it's the Borg's native name. It's never been explained why the name for the Borg is so close to the English word "cyborg".

table.name: mem
table.column: a very small bird whose eggs are considered quite tasty
Possibly based on bulgur (which is written البرغل in Arabic).

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {bIr; bortaS rur@@bIr:v, bortaS:n, rur:v}.
▶ {bortaS nIvqu' 'oH bortaS'e'.:sen} ▶ {bortaS bIr jablu'DI' reH QaQqu' nay'.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: bortaS bIr jablu'DI' reH QaQqu' nay'.
Revenge is a dish which is best served cold.

This is a very famous Klingon proverb.
There is also a related idiom {bIr; bortaS rur@@bIr:v, bortaS:n, rur:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The German word for "forbidden" is ver"bot"en.
▶ {Dubotchugh yIpummoH.:sen}[2] ▶ {qarDaSQa'Daq ruDelya' rop'a' Hergh qengbogh yo' Dabot.} "Intercept Rudellian plague relief convoy to Cardassian Union."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to the force field ({Surchem:n}) surrounding a spaceship. For hand-held shields, see {yoD:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
For the area between two (or more) objects, see {joj:n}. For the interior of an object in general, see {qoD:n}.
This word is also used in mathematics (see {botlh:n:2}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the "middle" value of a group of numbers. It's just the application of {botlh:n:1} in the context of mathematics.

table.name: mem
table.column: This could be used to refer to an ancient period in paleontology.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is used to remove food from {'un:n}.
This word is used in the idioms {bo'Dagh'a' lo':sen} and {bo'DaghHom lo':sen}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This expression has the negative connotation of exaggerating when it is inappropriate to do so.

table.name: mem
table.column: This expression has the negative connotation of minimizing the importance of something when it is inappropriate to do so.

table.name: mem
table.column: bird, the most general word for a bird-like creature

Types of birds include: {borghel:n}, {cha'bIp:n}, {cha'Do':n}, {cha'naS:n}, {cha'par:n}, {cha'qu':n}, {Da'nal:n}, {Da'vI':n}, {Her'IS:n}, {jentu':n}, {lIr:n}, {lotlhmoq:n}, {notqa':n}, {parbIng:n}, {qanraD:n}, {qaryoq:n}, {qaryoq'a':n}, {qa'rol:n}, {ramjep:n:2}, {raw':n}, {toQ:n}, {vem'eq:n}, {vIlInHoD:n}, {waqboch:n}, {yatqap:n}, {'apuStoQ:n}, {'uSgheb:n}, and possibly {qISa'ruj:n}.
The Alfred Hitchcock movie "The Birds" takes place in Bodega Bay.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the institution of the court, a judicial organization.

table.name: mem
table.column: A golf course has a "slope rating" which is used to measure its difficulty for "bogey golfers".

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: "Drawer" is slang for "underwear", and "BVD" is a brand of men's underwear.

table.name: mem
table.column: The temperature words really are about temperature and not about effect or perception, so that clothing, for example, is not said to be "hot" or "cold" in Klingon (but the person wearing it is).[2]

This is a combination of {bIr:v} and {tuj:v}.
The clarification about clothing was made during the Q & A session at {qep'a' 27 (2020):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is gender-neutral. If a distinction is required, add {loD:n} or {be':n}.
Monk Boulevard is a major street in Montreal.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sense of a towel absorbing liquid. It is not used in the sense of absorbing information.
"Boom"s are used to absorb oil and other substances.

table.name: mem
table.column: A line which was cut from {Star Trek Into Darkness:src} reveals that this can mean to end a relationship: {'ej jIHvo' nIHDI' jIbup:sen@@'ej:conj, jIH:n:1h, -vo':n, nIH:v, -DI':v, jI-:v, bup:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The Klingon Dictionary was published by Pocket Books. See also {paq:n:1h}.
The 2009 {Star Trek:src} movie has a deleted scene with the line: {buqmeylIjDaq DIvI' De' pu'jInmey... 'ach pu'jInmeylIj bIHbe'.:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a line in "Lady Madonna" by The Beatles: "Friday night arrives without a suitcase."

table.name: mem
table.column: A Terran trombone would be a {tera' buq'ach:n@@tera':n, buq'ach:n}.[1]
The "sackbut" ({buq:n}, {'ach:conj}) is a type of trombone.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a reference to "Rubik's Cube". It is, of course, scrambled.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is also used to express the concept of "leap year" ({bur DIS:sen}).

table.name: mem
table.column: To express the concept of a "leap year", just use the verb {bur:v} with {DIS:n:2}.
This was revealed to provide Klingon subtitles for the 50th anniversary of the German children's TV show "Die Sendung mit der Maus".

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to an internal organ, of which Klingons have two (see {bIraqlul:n}). To refer to the exterior midsection of the body, use {chor:n:1} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: The definition actually says "naturally produced kud" in the K-E word list and "naturally produced qud" in the E-K word list.

table.name: mem
table.column: concentrate on, focus on, think only about

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Qu' buSHa'chugh SuvwI', batlhHa' vangchugh, qoj matlhHa'chugh, pagh ghaH SuvwI''e'.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to an individual thought, something thought of or about, something conceived of, a mental object or construct.
This was rumoured to have been revealed at {qep'a' 26 (2019):src}, and was confirmed at {qep'a' 27 (2020):src} during the Q & A session.

table.name: mem
table.column: [1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - Si Vis Pacem, Para Bellum:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the radioactive chemical element with the symbol Pu and atomic number 94.

table.name: mem
table.column: quality that is similar to what humans call "gall"
This is an admirable trait to have.

table.name: mem
table.column: Admire the person with dirt under his fingernails.

table.name: mem
table.column:
See {Hung buv rav:n} for an example of how to talk about classified information.
This can refer to a "category" (i.e., a related group) of {DuH:n} in a {SeHlaw:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: For the "secret information" sense of "classified", see {pegh:v:2}. See also {rav:n:2} for an example of how to talk about classified information.

table.name: mem
table.column: This cannot be used to say that a person is "full" (i.e., not hungry).[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: good news, it's good to hear that

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the highest rank of {QaS:n:1h}.
